channel.title: Matthew Rocklin
channel.description: Personal site of Matthew Rocklin - thoughts on open source, startups, and engineering

item.title: Home
item.description:

Matthew Rocklin

Hello ðŸ‘‹!

My name is Matt, and I write software.

I work in the open source Python...

item.title: AI Zealotry
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: Senior engineers are best positioned to benefit from AI. We're good enough to avoid slop, and there's so much we can accomplish. I wouldn't go back.

item.title: Audio-Visual Setup
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: How we present ourselves has unreasonable effectiveness on perception. An excellent Zoom setup costs $2000 and a dayâ€”anyone can achieve the unfair advantage that tall people have naturally.

item.title: Avoid Indirection
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: Abstraction has costs. Every layer you add is another place readers have to look. Sometimes the clearest code is the most direct.

item.title: Biased Benchmarks
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: Fair benchmarks are surprisingly difficult even with best intentions. We judge others by our objectives, fail to use their projects with expertise, and gravitate toward cases where we excel.

item.title: Brevity
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: Speaking truth is easy. Getting people to listen is hard. Practical advice on respecting your reader through an attention span budget.

item.title: I Walked across Spain
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: Reflections from 27 days and 500 miles across Spain. The overlapping physical, social, cultural, and spiritual layers that make this pilgrimage meaningfully different.

item.title: Cloud Computing is Broken
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: What hunger am I seeing on the ground? Boring shit. People struggle most with the basics of cloud computing. The promise remains undelivered.

item.title: Decision Fatigue
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: When you hit a roadblock, don't ask "what should we do?" Own the problem. Propose a solution. Help your team by carrying the weight yourself.

item.title: Listen to Sell
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: Resist the urge to answer technical questions. We want to show off how things work, but we often dive too deep before understanding the customer's actual problem.

item.title: Fail in public
item.description: title: Twitter, LinkedIn, and Failing in Public tagline: What I miss about Twitter-that-was. description: LinkedIn shows only the final act. We connect t...

item.title: Failure
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: Someone has to pay the psychological cost of uncertainty. I choose honesty, even when it has negative consequences.

item.title: Small Scope Reviews
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: A fast review cycle is incredibly valuable. Distinguish obligatory comments that stop regressions from commendable ones that add enhancements. Better is the enemy of good.

item.title: Feedback
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: Open source code review taught me to give intense, detailed feedback. Then I became a manager and learned why that doesn't always translate.

item.title: Hammers and Nailguns
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: A nailgun puts nails into wood. A hammer whacks things. Simple tools with humble opinions are more versatile than specialized ones.

item.title: Hiring Sales
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: We fired the sales team when our product was bad. Now it's good. Finding the right early sales hire is an interesting challenge.

item.title: Interviews
item.description: title: How I Conduct an Interview tagline: Interviewing is hard. It's also important to do well. description: My approach to 45-minute interviews: what I...

item.title: Laser Eye Correction
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: From deciding to explore the procedure to having my eyes lasered in two weeks. Long, rambling, and nothing to do with startups or tech.

item.title: How I Almost Quit My Job, and How Being Selfish Saved Me
item.author: Matthew Rocklin
item.description: When a small amount of your work helps others a great deal, of course you sacrifice. You'd be a monster not to. But your ego can fade in service of your project.
